name: Amy Winehouse
description:
'''Amy Jade Winehouse''' (14 September 1983 â€“ 23 July 2011) was an English singer, songwriter, musician, and businesswoman. She was known for her distinctive [[contralto]] vocals, expressive and [[Autobiography|autobiographical]] songwriting, and eclectic blend of genres such as [[Soul music|soul]], [[rhythm and blues]], and [[jazz]]. [[Amy Winehouse in popular culture|A cultural icon]] of the 21st century, Winehouse sold over 30 million records worldwide and won six [[Grammy Awards]] among [[List of awards and nominations received by Amy Winehouse|other accolades]]. 

Winehouse was a member of the [[National Youth Jazz Orchestra]] in her youth, signing to [[Simon Fuller]]'s [[19 Management]] in 2002 and soon recording a number of songs before signing a publishing deal with [[EMI]]. She also formed a working relationship with producer [[Salaam Remi]] through these record publishers. Winehouse's debut album, ''[[Frank (Amy Winehouse album)|Frank]]'', was released in 2003. Many of the album's songs were influenced by jazz and, apart from two [[Cover version|covers]], were co-written by Winehouse. ''Frank'' was a critical and commercial success in the UK, and beyond, and was nominated for the UK's [[Mercury Prize]]. The song "[[Stronger Than Me]]" won her the [[Ivor Novello Award]] for Best Contemporary Song from the [[British Academy of Songwriters, Composers and Authors]].

Winehouse released her follow-up album, ''[[Back to Black]]'', in 2006. The album went on to become a huge international success and one of the [[List of best-selling albums|best-selling albums of all time]], as well as one of the [[List of best-selling albums in the United Kingdom|best-selling albums in UK history]]. At the [[2007 Brit Awards]], it was nominated for [[Brit Award for British Album of the Year|British Album of the Year]] and Winehouse received the award for [[Brit Award for British Female Solo Artist|British Female Solo Artist]]. The song "[[Rehab (Amy Winehouse song)|Rehab]]" won her a second Ivor Novello Award. At the [[50th Grammy Awards]] in 2008, she won five awards, tying the then [[Grammy Award records#Most Grammys won by a female artist in one night|record for the most wins by a female artist in a single night]] and becoming the first British woman to win five Grammys. These included three of the [[General Field "Big Four" Grammy Award]]s: [[2008 General Field "Big Four" Grammy Award|Best New Artist, Record of the Year and Song of the Year]] (for "Rehab"), as well as [[Best Pop Vocal Album]].

Winehouse struggled throughout her life with [[substance abuse]], [[mental illness]] and addiction. She died at her [[Camden Square]] home in London of [[alcohol poisoning]] in 2011 at the age of 27, prompting media references to the [[27 Club]]. Her brother believed that [[bulimia]] was also a factor. After her death, ''Back to Black'' briefly became the UK's best-selling album of the 21st century. Her life and career was also depicted in a 2015 documentary, [[Amy (2015 film)|''Amy'']], and dramatised in a 2024 biopic, ''[[Back to Black (film)|Back to Black]]''. She appears on several professional listings of the greatest singers, including [[VH1]]'s "[[The Greatest (VH1 TV series)|100 Greatest Women in Music]]"  and ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'s}} "200 Greatest Singers of All Time". In 2025, ''Back to Black'' was preserved in the [[National Recording Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]].
